{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3271348,"name":null,"username":"Notmark","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/a6a055/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-01-02T18:14:24.157Z","cooked":"

Hello,
During this off-season I was curious to try out the new configurable model type in Fusion 360. I decided to put together a crayola CAD version and then a configurable model(kinda) of a generic MK4I Swerve drive chassis.

The full model incorporates(or tries to):

  • Parametric Frame dimensions
  • Optionally center beams
  • Optional cutout
    Feel free to download the models here to toy around with or use:
    Parameterized FRC Frames by notMarc - Thingiverse
    and here
    https://grabcad.com/library/frc-chassis-configurable-crayola-cad-1

As I was working with the final model where bodies/components were being created and removed in different configurations, it started to break the model as I swapped through the different configs.

Does anybody have any guidelines and recommendations for working with configurable files in Fusion? Not specifically in relation to what I was working on(I don’t plan on taking them any farther for this season), just general best practices would be great to hear.

Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-01-02T18:14:24.157Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":35,"reads":99,"readers_count":98,"score":194.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":447216,"topic_slug":"best-practices-for-configurable-fusion-360-models-configurable-drivetrain-models","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6413282","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":11},{"url":"https://grabcad.com/library/frc-chassis-configurable-crayola-cad-1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57921,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/best-practices-for-configurable-fusion-360-models-configurable-drivetrain-models/447216/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3271826,"name":"Robert Woodhead","username":"MadOverlord","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/madoverlord/{size}/163860_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-03T10:40:01.287Z","cooked":"

My general troubleshooting process when a parameter change causes the model to break is to back up the timeline to a point just before the first error or warning, single-step forward (so there’s only one broken command), and then look at the error message and try and figure out what’s causing it. Sometimes it’s obvious from how the model has rendered up until that point what’s causing the problem, and often the problem is an earlier command.

As a general rule of thumb, do cleanup/esthetic stuff like fillets and chamfers last; they are often the source of errors.

Note that some parametric changes (especially if they are significant in magnitude) are going to break the model no matter what, because if they result in things like whole faces appearing or disappearing, all bets are off.

Thanks,
I can definitely make better use of the timeline for troubleshooting and concentrating on core features at the beginning of the modeling process. I’ll keep this in mind going into the build season
